Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: When loading cargo, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Stack items as high as possible.
questions.answerB: Know the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.
questions.answerC: Place light items underneath heavier items.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles use the ____ method when changing gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with unsynchronized manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears.

questions.question: A truck should be parked:
questions.answerA: So that it must be backed up to leave the space.
questions.answerB: So that it can be pulled forward to leave the space.
questions.explanation: Because you can't see everything behind you, backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. Choose parking spaces from which you can pull forward when you leave.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.answerB: 2 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Causing a fatality through negligent operation of a CMV will result in the loss of your CDL for a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.explanation: A first conviction of causing a fatality through negligent operation of a CMV will result in the loss of your CDL for at least one year.

questions.question: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerB: The total distance traveled
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the dates of a trip and the total distance traveled by the vehicle.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: ____ are the most likely to be affected by strong winds.
questions.answerB: Heavy vehicles
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.answerB: While in the curve
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerB: Using your senses
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerB: Take special care to be driven.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: When using a mirror, you should:
questions.answerB: Stare at the mirror for a long time.
questions.answerC: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: When making mirror checks, you should look at the mirrors fairly quickly. If you spend too much time looking in a mirror, you may travel a substantial distance down the road without seeing what is coming up ahead.

questions.question: Texting while driving should:
questions.answerB: Only be done in curves.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is a dangerous distraction and is prohibited at all times when operating a CMV.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.answerB: Properly using turn signals.
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, your best hope to stop is to:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will have to look outside your vehicle for a way to stop. Using an escape ramp is the safest way to stop your vehicle.

questions.question: If approaching a vehicle with a distracted driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a distracted driver, give them plenty of space and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle and you are not sure how to extinguish it, you should:
questions.answerB: Try douse the flames with water.
questions.answerC: Move away from the flames and wait for the firefighters.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which method to use when putting out a fire, do not attempt to extinguish the fire on your own. Instead, wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially true if you are experiencing a hazardous materials fire.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your vehicle in front of them.
questions.answerB: Make eye contact with them
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, don't let yourself be provoked by their actions or angry gestures. Do not risk provoking the other driver by making eye contact. Get out of their way if you can do so safely.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: To prevent becoming an aggressive driver you should:
questions.answerB: Make gestures at other drivers.
questions.answerC: Give other drivers the benefit of the doubt.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in aggressive driving behavior, it is helpful to give other drivers the benefit of the doubt. Assume that they have valid reasons for what they are doing and don't take their actions personally.

questions.question: When backing up, follow a turning trailer by:
questions.answerA: Changing nothing. The vehicle will naturally follow the trailer.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel even harder in the direction that it is already turning.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of ____ tie-downs.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerB: Rely on the actions of other motorists to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Not rely solely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should not rely solely upon the presence of warning signals, gates, or flaggers to alert you to the approach of a train. Be especially alert to approaching trains at crossings that are not controlled by gates or signals. At any railroad crossing, you should operate under the assumption that a train is coming.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: What is a drawback of retarders?
questions.answerA: They may not be permitted everywhere.
questions.answerB: They can help to slow a vehicle.
questions.explanation: A retarder is a device that helps to slow a vehicle, reducing the need for a driver to use the brakes. However, these devices can be noisy and are not permitted everywhere.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes:
questions.answerA: Other vehicles will likely get out of your way.
questions.answerB: You should change lanes slowly and smoothly.
questions.answerC: You should wait to change lanes until you are in an intersection.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should always be executed slowly and smoothly. This will result in safer handling of your vehicle while allowing time for other drivers to react to your movements.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: Reading a text message while driving is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only if you are not pulling a trailer.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is both dangerous and illegal.

questions.question: If an Anti-Locking Braking System (ABS) is not working on a truck:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at low speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise toward the normal operating range.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.answerB: A school bus
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.answerB: A loud horn
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Under-inflate your tires.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Lower the tire's air pressure.
questions.answerC: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: What is traction?
questions.answerA: Friction between the tires and road
questions.answerB: Tires' rates of rotation
questions.answerC: The length of time needed to activate the brakes
questions.explanation: Traction is friction between your tires and the surface of the road. Adequate traction is necessary for braking and steering.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: In cool weather, as the temperature begins to rise and ice begins to melt:
questions.answerA: It is usually safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become even more slippery.
questions.explanation: As the temperature begins to rise and ice on the road begins to melt, the road surface will often become even more slippery. Water from the slight melting will sit on top of the ice, decreasing the available traction even more. Always decrease your speed and drive with caution when traveling on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerB: Take special care to be driven.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged in inclement weather.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Distracted driving can be avoided by:
questions.answerB: Smoking while driving.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerB: Ammonia
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerB: A dangerous activity.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Pull into a service station.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: What should be done before transporting an over-length load?
questions.answerA: Special transit permits should be acquired.
questions.answerB: Fire departments along the route should be alerted.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits from the Department of Transportation.

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.answerB: Maintain contact with the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.answerB: Replace an electrical fuse.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.explanation: The adjustment of your mirrors should be checked prior to the start of all trips. Adjust your mirrors as needed.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: Using the brakes creates heat. If too much heat is produced:
questions.answerB: The brakes may squeak more than usual.
questions.explanation: Brakes are designed to take a lot of heat, but drivers should not rely solely on the brakes to slow their vehicle. Brakes may fade and lose their ability to slow down the vehicle if they become too hot, so drivers should also rely on the engine braking effect.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.answerB: Properly tightened.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: For the proper amount of brake fluid.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerA: Allowed if you are contacting your employer.
questions.answerB: Allowed when driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is dangerous and is never permitted while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerB: Tire pressure is too low.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your vehicle in front of them.
questions.answerB: Make eye contact with them
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, don't let yourself be provoked by their actions or angry gestures. Do not risk provoking the other driver by making eye contact. Get out of their way if you can do so safely.

questions.question: While driving, gauges are:
questions.answerB: Unpredictable.
questions.answerC: To be monitored for potential signs of trouble.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should watch your vehicle's gauges for signs of trouble. Be sure to inspect your gauges before beginning a trip to ensure that they are in proper working order.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: Heights posted at bridges:
questions.answerB: Are legally binding.
questions.explanation: Never assume that the posted height on a bridge or other overhead object is correct. Even if it was accurate when posted, things may have changed that affect clearance, either permanently (such as a repaving of the road) or temporarily (such as packed snow on the road).

questions.question: Roads are the most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with the oil and grease on the road that have not yet washed away.
questions.answerB: Roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed into the middle of the lane.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: 1/8 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.answerB: Trailer air supply control
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerB: Usually thin.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: When making a lane change, your turn signal:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if there is traffic present.
questions.answerC: Should only be used between dusk and dawn.
questions.explanation: You must always properly signal before turning or changing lanes.

questions.question: Oversized loads:
questions.answerA: Can never be transported by a truck.
questions.answerB: Should only be transported during the day.
questions.answerC: Should receive proper authorization to ensure compliance with state and local laws.
questions.explanation: Special permits are required for loads that are over-size, over-length, or overweight.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerB: When making a turn.
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerB: Checked frequently.
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: While driving, if you notice anything that affects safety or could lead to mechanical problems, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait to see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Include the concerns in your written report.
questions.answerC: Try to fix the issue yourself.
questions.explanation: After finishing a day of driving, you may have to complete a written report on the condition of your vehicle. Be sure to mention anything that could affect safety or lead to mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Increase gradually.
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerB: Helps to stabilize the load.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: The center of gravity in a trailer should be:
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle should be distributed as low as possible. Having a center of gravity that is too high will increase the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in a higher gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid nitrogen
questions.explanation: The brakes in an air brake system use compressed air to function properly.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerB: The speed of the road (mph).
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate especially slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To keep from accelerating faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under slippery conditions. Using too much power in such conditions may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: What is Gross Combination Weight?
questions.answerA: The total weight of the powered unit, trailer, and cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a single vehicle without its load
questions.answerC: The maximum weight allowed by the manufacturer
questions.explanation: Gross Combination Weight (GCW) is the total weight of a powered unit, its trailer(s), and the cargo being carried.

questions.question: How can you check hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should move slowly toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive as fast as possible.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.answerB: Low pressure warning device
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should only be done in poor weather.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used to prevent cargo from sliding while in transit.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.answerB: Hazardous materials
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-downs.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerB: Is discouraged.
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerB: Drive around any lowered gates.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.answerB: 2 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Adjust your driving to match weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On a slippery road, you must adjust your driving speed to fit conditions. Because it will take longer for your vehicle to stop on a slippery road than on a dry road, you should increase your following distance when conditions are slippery. Avoid driving in a way that requires you to change speeds frequently.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles have front brake limiting valves with "normal" and "slippery" settings. Setting a brake limiting valve to "slippery" reduces the vehicle's stopping power, so a driver should make sure the valve is in its "normal" position. Front wheel braking has proven to be effective in all driving conditions.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.answerC: May be slower to make critical decisions than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: Fatigued drivers are slower to see or react to hazards than drivers who are not fatigued. Drivers are impaired in their ability to make critical decisions when they are driving drowsy.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Keep cargo in a large box.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from sliding in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from falling out of a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking may be used on all sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.answerB: Parking brakes
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Place weight over only the axles.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: Do not operate a vehicle if any brake drums have cracks that are larger than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.answerB: One third
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: While driving, gauges are:
questions.answerB: Unpredictable.
questions.answerC: To be monitored for potential signs of trouble.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should watch your vehicle's gauges for signs of trouble. Be sure to inspect your gauges before beginning a trip to ensure that they are in proper working order.

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: The heavier the vehicle:
questions.answerA: The less important the brakes become.
questions.answerB: The harder the brakes need to work.
questions.answerC: The quieter the brakes will sound.
questions.explanation: The heavier a vehicle is, the more the brakes will need to work to bring the vehicle to a complete stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: 1/8 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: If convicted of any traffic violations, excluding parking violations, you must:
questions.answerB: Place a sign on the back of your vehicle noting the conviction.
questions.answerC: Forfeit your CDL for six months.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Steering wheel play of more than ____ can make steering difficult.
questions.answerB: 25 degrees
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open their door for a better look.
questions.answerB: Use their mirrors.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerB: The gas pedal is loose.
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.answerB: Valve stems without damage.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.answerB: Leaves can be missing.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: Using a helper when backing up a large vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: Backing a CMV is always dangerous due to limited visibility, so using a helper to monitor your blind spots is encouraged whenever possible.

questions.question: When should mirror adjustments be made?
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.answerC: When a vehicle is stopped at a traffic signal
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of each trip. Any attached trailer should be straight while mirrors are being adjusted.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerB: You should not tell anyone.
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: What is a drawback of retarders?
questions.answerA: They may not be permitted everywhere.
questions.answerB: They can help to slow a vehicle.
questions.explanation: A retarder is a device that helps to slow a vehicle, reducing the need for a driver to use the brakes. However, these devices can be noisy and are not permitted everywhere.

questions.question: Overloading a vehicle with cargo:
questions.answerA: Usually has no effect on the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can impact the vehicle's steering and brake control.
questions.answerC: Can impact the vehicle's electrical system.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle can have negative effects on steering, braking, and speed control. Learn to recognize when cargo is overloaded or poorly balanced.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure a 10-foot piece of cargo?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: When transporting a load, the cargo should be inspected:
questions.answerA: Only at the beginning of a drive.
questions.answerB: Only after driving a long distance.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts could be loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: If a speed limit is posted, the posted speed:
questions.answerB: May be exceeded if passing another vehicle.
questions.answerC: May be exceeded if driving in a rural area.
questions.explanation: A maximum posted speed limit is the fastest a vehicle may travel under ideal circumstances. A driver should decrease their driving speed as conditions require. A driver should never exceed the legal speed limit.

questions.question: A driver may have:
questions.answerA: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.answerB: Only one license.
questions.answerC: Two licenses: one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerB: Use both side mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Five to six seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign that brakes will need repair?
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: Texting while operating a CMV is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable on rural roads.
questions.answerC: Acceptable for drivers contacting their employers.
questions.explanation: Texting and driving is dangerous for everyone on the road. It is illegal to text while operating a CMV.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at them.
questions.explanation: If you encounter a driver who seems distracted on the road, you should give them plenty of room and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: When conducting a check of the engine compartment during a vehicle inspection, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: Manual air tank drains should be:
questions.answerA: Opened to drain the tanks after each day.
questions.answerB: Left open while driving.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.answerB: A loud horn
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Shortens brake response time.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps to provide additional control during hard braking, but does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: If you are disqualified from driving:
questions.answerA: Your employer will be notified by the state.
questions.answerB: You must notify your employer within two business days.
questions.answerC: You must notify your employer within a month.
questions.explanation: You must notify your employer within two business days if your license is suspended, revoked, or canceled, or if you are otherwise disqualified from driving.

questions.question: When should a driver sign a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerB: If noted defects are repaired
questions.explanation: You must sign a vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and either certified to have been repaired or certified as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: When you are about to start down a hill, you should switch into a ____ gear.
questions.answerB: Faster
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: Without the proper amount of oil in its engine:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will have difficulty stopping.
questions.answerB: A vehicle will make quick, jerking movements while being driven.
questions.answerC: The engine may be quickly damaged.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a vehicle's engine have adequate oil pressure. An engine can be destroyed rapidly if it is run without oil.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid air
questions.explanation: Air brakes function through the use of compressed air.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.answerC: Inspected, but only about once a month.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to introduce alcohol into air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Only allowed in the northern parts of the state.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems have alcohol evaporators, which introduce alcohol into the braking system to help prevent the formation of ice.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.answerB: Securely connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: The two markings on a front brake limiting valve usually read:
questions.answerB: "Low" and "high."
questions.explanation: Some vehicles with air brake systems manufactured before 1975 have a front brake limiting valve with "normal" and "slippery" settings.

questions.question: When transporting a load, you should inspect the cargo:
questions.answerB: At the end of each day.
questions.answerC: Every time you take a break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securement must be inspected every time you take a break during a trip. Be sure to inspect the cargo at least every 150 miles.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.explanation: It is important that the driver of a CMV always downshifts before entering a curve.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
